content: The Great Lakes watershed, spanning 300,000 square miles across eight U.S. states and one Canadian province, holds nearly 90% of the U.S. surface freshwater and 20% of the world's. It is vital for national and international economies, supporting 40 million people and diverse natural resources. The Great Lakes are of international importance due to their abundant natural resources and economic significance to the United States and Canada. Nearly 90% of the US surface freshwater and 20% of the world's freshwater are found in the Great Lakes. The basin supports a growing population of 40 million people who rely on it for jobs, drinking water, and recreation. The Great Lakes have been significantly altered over the past two centuries due to agricultural, urban, and industrial development. Development in the Great Lakes basin has led to degraded water quality, posing threats to wildlife and human health. Urban and industrial activities have altered habitats, introduced non-native species, and contaminated sediments. Over 50 species are listed as at risk due to these changes. Development in the Great Lakes basin, including urban and industrial activities along the shoreline, has degraded water quality and led to changes in habitats, introduction of non-native species, sediment contamination, and endangerment of over 50 species. Restoration efforts by the U.S. and Canadian governments are underway to address these issues. The U.S. Congress and other governments are implementing restoration activities in the Great Lakes basin to address water quality degradation, habitat changes, and species endangerment. Congress has enacted over 30 federal laws focused on restoring the basin, authorizing various programs from toxic substance mitigation to improving water quality and wildlife habitat. The U.S. Congress has enacted more than 30 federal laws focused on restoring the Great Lakes basin, authorizing activities such as grant programs for toxic substance mitigation and restoration programs for water quality and wildlife habitat. However, there is no legislation for an overall detailed restoration plan like the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan in Florida.
